I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to India for the Bihar Power System Improvement Project. The report also describes proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  Bihar  Power  Sector  Capacity  Development  and 
Implementation Support, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
2.  The project will upgrade the electric power system, increase efficiency, reliability and 
quality of supply through physical investments in the power infrastructure of the state of Bihar, 
coupled with a capacity development component. Project investments include installation of 
new, and renovation and modernization (R&M) of existing transmission substations; installation 
of  new,  and reinforcement  of existing transmission  lines;  and the  improving  of  distribution 
systems in seven towns in Bihar. This will reduce system bottlenecks, boost power supply and 
system reliability, and minimize technical and commercial losses. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  India's annual economic growth rate of over 8% since 2008 has accelerated energy 
needs.  Suffering  nationwide  from  peak  power  deficits  of  around  12%,  India  has  identified 
infrastructure improvements and better electric power supply as a key feature of its drive to 
sustain high growth levels. Currently, only about 60% of Indian households have access to 
electricity. Adequate supply is essential for sustained economic growth and poverty reduction. 
 
4.  While India has emerged as one of the fastest-growing countries in the world, Bihar—
with a population of 90 million and a per capita income of around $160—remains one of its 
poorest states. One in seven of India's poor resides in Bihar, and about 40% of the population 
lives below the poverty line, compared with 23% nationally. Per capita consumption of electricity 
in Bihar was approximately 100 kilowatt-hours (kWh) per annum in FY2007,2 compared with a 
national average of over 700 kWh. In FY2008, Bihar faced energy shortages of 28% and peak 
power shortages 16%. However, the true extent of unserved and suppressed demand is difficult 
to gauge as supply has been irregular for so long.  
 
5.  Bihar's power sector is in need of investment. Insufficient capacity of its transmission 
network restrains reliability, quality, and stability of power supply. Bihar's electricity distribution 
network  has  failed  to  keep  pace  with  growing  demand.  Power  transformer  capacity  is 
inadequate to meet demand on 11 kilovolt (kV) feeders in many areas, 33 kV and 11 kV feeders 
are being loaded above thermal limits, and failure rates for distribution transformers are about 
19%. Undersized conductors, long low-voltage circuits, and overloaded distribution transformers 
further impair quality of supply. Overall, system losses exceed 40%. This is a considerable drag 
on sector finances and sustainability.  
 
6.  Though Bihar needs more generation capacity to begin closing the supply–demand gap, 
boosting generation is a relatively low priority because Bihar is able to buy power from the 
central  generation  utilities  and  from  independent  generators.  Upgrading  transmission  and 
distribution  systems,  and  reducing  system  losses,  is  thus  a first  and more  essential  step,

particularly since adding generation will be more efficient and cost-effective once system losses 
are contained. The proposed project will address these concerns in four distribution circles 
(seven towns) within the state,3 and through two transmission system upgrade components.4 
The capacity development component will deal with constraints in managerial and engineering 
practices that have contributed to the high system losses. 
 
7.  Upgrading the transmission and distribution (T&D) systems is one of four power sector 
priorities in the Government of India's 11th Five Year Plan.5 This project is thus consistent with 
the  government's  strategy,  and  the  India  country  partnership  and  strategy  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), which complements the government's strategy and specifies ADB 
support  of  energy  initiatives  in  India,  including  expanding  and  optimizing  T&D  systems, 
providing institutional strengthening, and encouraging energy efficiency and conservation.6  
 
8.  The  project  also  reflects  lessons  from  previous  ADB  interventions.  The  country 
assistance program evaluation,7 conducted in 2007, notes that ADB's sector performance is 
rated successful because most ADB assistance helped build much-needed infrastructure and 
contributed to the improvement of sector policy and institutional environments. This evaluation 
stresses the need to stay focused on states that suffer from high poverty levels, low levels of 
social development, weak capacity and poor infrastructure. Also in 2007, a sector assistance 
program evaluation of India’s energy sector identified the following main lessons: (i) ADB’s 
approach to lending at the state level has worked well and should be used as a model for future 
assistance;  (ii)  sustained  technical  assistance  has  been  crucial  to  the  success  of  state 
programs, both before and after loans were made; and (iii) corporatization via the introduction of 
commercially and financially sustainable principles into state entities, and increasing the quality 
of governments can considerably improve efficiency and deliver better services to customers.8 
 
9.  These experiences are reflected in the design and preparation of the project, as this is 
ADB's first power sector intervention in Bihar—a state with a high level of poverty and significant 
needs  for  upgraded  electricity  infrastructure.  The  project  is  accompanied  by  TA  aimed  at 
capacity  development  and  improvements  in  financial  management  and  governance. 
Furthermore, capacity-building efforts in the Bihar power sector have been ongoing for several 
years to (i) prepare the project, including an existing technical assistance program analyzing the 
state’s power system and preparing a 10-year investment plan, and providing training for and 
computerization  of  system  planning;9 and  (ii)  to  train  key  executing  agency  staff  on  ADB 
procurement and disbursement guidelines. Regarding improving sector policy and institutional 
environments, the Government of Bihar is in the process of planning the restructuring and 
unbundling  activities  of  the  Bihar  State  Electricity  Board  (BSEB)  in  accordance  with  the 
Electricity Act, 2003.

B.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be a more sustainable state power sector able to provide better services 
to end users. The outcome will be stronger T&D capacity, greater T&D system efficiency, and 
higher quality and reliability of service in Bihar. Specifically, the investment components will 
focus on seven towns within four of the 16 distribution circles in Bihar.10   
 
C.  Outputs 
11.  Outputs include T&D system components, and a capacity development component. 
Transmission component outputs include (i) transmission expansion via one new 220/132 kV 
grid substation at Pusauli, (ii)  two new 132/33 kV substations, at Dhanha and Gangwara, 
(iii) erection of additional 132 kV bays at six existing substations, (iv) erection of additional 
220 kV bays at the Dehri substation, (v) erection of new 33 kV bays - 10 each at Gangwara and 
Dhanha (both at the substation end and remote end), and (vi) approximately 368 kilometers 
(km) of new transmission lines (consisting of 33 kV, 132 kV, and 220 kV lines). Distribution 
component  outputs  include  the  following  to  be  implemented  in  seven  towns  within  Bihar 
(footnote 10): (i) construction of 33/11 kV substations and R&M of existing 33/11 kV substations, 
(ii) construction of 33 kV, 11 kV and low-tension lines, and R&M of existing lines, (iii) installation 
of new distribution transformers and capacity augmentation and R&M of existing transformers, 
and  (iv)  installation  and/or  replacement  of  consumer  metering  equipment.  The  capacity 
development  component  is  designed  to  assist  the  executing  agency,  BSEB,  with  project 
implementation support and construction supervision as this is its first loan from a multilateral 
development  institution.  This  component  also  includes  training  in  high-voltage  distribution 
systems and will fund feasibility studies for a small project to pilot high-voltage distribution 
systems,  as  well  as  other  training  programs  on  financial  management  and  corporate  and 
managerial planning.11  
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
 
12.  The project is estimated to cost $153.9 million. The government has requested a loan of 
$132.2 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. The loan will 
have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, an annual interest rate determined in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year (the interest and other charges during construction to be 
capitalized in the loan), and such other terms and conditions as set forth in the draft loan and 
project agreements. The government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to 
borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these terms and conditions, and (ii) 
an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not made in reliance 
on any communication or advice from ADB. The investment plan is summarized in Table 1.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
17.  TA for the Bihar Power Sector Capacity Development and Implementation Support, with 
a total cost of $350,000, is included in the 2010 country operations business plan.14  $300,000 
will be funded from ADB and $50,000 will be provided in-kind from the executing agency. The 
TA is attached to the loan and will target specific capacity development needs of the executing 
agency, particularly the most urgent needs associated with project implementation. The impact 
will be stronger institutional capacity on general project implementation matters. The outcome 
will be solid implementation of the Bihar Power System Improvement Project combined with 
knowledge transfer.15  
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
18.  The selected investment components have been subject to rigorous scrutiny. They were 
examined  by  BSEB,  the  Ministry  of  Power,  and  the  Central  Electricity  Authority  of  the 
Government of India16 for their technical, economic, and financial feasibility. ADB staff also 
reviewed all aspects of the subprojects. ADB’s loan processing missions visited sites, reviewed 
all  available  reports,  and  undertook  a  comprehensive  due  diligence  assessment,  including

safeguard  aspects  of  the  project,  and  note  that  the  project  is  technically,  financially,  and 
economically viable. Best practice design standards and construction techniques will be applied. 
 
A.  Technical 
19.  ADB has reviewed and confirmed the technical viability. The transmission components 
to be financed by ADB are part of BSEB’s transmission expansion plan. Development of the 
plan tends to follow an iterative process in which requirements for national grid offtake and 
power substation (33/11 kV) supply are matched, so as to determine the least-cost means of 
developing the transmission network under a reasonable range of scenarios. In this sense, the 
transmission  master  plan  is  the  least-cost  means  of  achieving  a  desired  set  of  electricity 
transmission outcomes. Regarding the distribution system, there are no viable alternatives to 
substation and transformer modernization, line upgrades, and system metering. The proposed 
investment  components fit  in  with  the master plan  developed for the  state's  power  sector 
(footnote 9).17 Technical specifications and line diagrams for the proposed substations were 
reviewed, supply and installation costs analyzed, and technical loss reductions through some 
investments under the project quantified. Project designs will be (i) consistent with overall least-
cost  expansion  plans;  (ii)  have  a  least-cost  basis;  and  (iii)  reflect  best-practice  design, 
construction,  and  operation  and maintenance features.  Investment  components  will feature 
performance-based design consistent with international benchmarks for system efficiency and 
operating risk. The capacity development component will fund construction oversight services. 
Furthermore, the attached TA provides implementation support.   
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
20.  Economic analysis was undertaken for the investments under the loan. A time-slice 
approach was adopted for detailed economic cost–benefit analysis, taking into consideration the 
entire T&D system investment program for the state (which includes the investment components 
funded by the Bihar Power System Improvement Project), as detailed in the Bihar power system 
master plan. This was done to avoid the difficulties inherent in allocating costs and benefits to 
individual components, given the poor condition of most of Bihar’s electricity networks. The main 
economic benefits of the proposed investments are incremental consumption, and displacement 
of  thermal  electricity  and  self-generation  from  diesel  plants.  Incremental  consumption  was 
valued at consumers’ estimated willingness to pay for it. Displaced thermal generation was 
valued at estimated long-run, average incremental cost of power supply to Bihar, calculated 
from the generation part of the power system master plan. Displaced self-generation was valued 
at the variable cost of an average diesel generator. 
 
21.  A  ―with-project‖  and  ―without-project‖  approach  was  adopted  for  the  purposes  of 
analysis.  It  was  assumed  that  in  the  without-project  case,  network  outages,  losses,  and 
unserved demand would increase in proportion to forecast demand. In the with-project case, it 
was  assumed  that  outages,  losses,  and  unserved  demand  would  decrease  over  time  as 
network constraints are relieved.18  
 
22.  A period of 25 years has been used for economic evaluation, including 8 years for 
capital investment and construction. Investment is assumed to take place in 2010–2017, and

7 
benefits  are  assumed  to  be  realized  progressively  from  2011.  The  detailed  cost–benefit 
calculations  show  that  the  overall  power  system  master  plan  investment  program  is 
economically viable, with an estimated economic internal rate of return of 26.5%.19  
 
23.  Financial analysis of components to be funded from the proposed loan was carried out in 
accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.20 Incremental costs 
and  benefits  were  computed  based on  with-project  and  without-project  scenarios for  each 
component. The costs include land acquisition, civil works, equipment, incremental operating 
and maintenance costs, and distribution cost. BSEB has limited energy and power metering 
within its network, with no practical means to isolate and measure the direct benefits of the 
investment components. Therefore, the annual revenue requirement approach was used to 
determine the financial benefits of the project components. This approach reflects the fact that 
BSEB will petition the Bihar Electricity Regulatory Commission to have the new investments 
added to BSEB’s regulatory asset base at the next tariff redetermination, with the result that the 
capital, operating, and replacement cost of the new assets will be included in the  annual 
revenue requirement against which BSEB will be able to charge its customers. This approach to 
tariff setting ensures that BSEB is able to recover costs and earn a sufficient return on its equity, 
and provides an incentive to BSEB to invest in network expansion. 
 
24.  Incremental cash flows attributable to the proposed investments were estimated based 
on the methodology and assumptions described above. The financial internal rates of return are 
estimated at 4.9% for the transmission component and at 7.6% for the distribution component. 
These returns compare favorably with the estimated value of weighted average cost of capital of 
2.8%, substantiating the financial viability of the investments.21  
 
C.  Governance 
25.  A governance assessment of the Bihar power sector was conducted, including public 
financial management, procurement activities, and anticorruption measures.  
 
26.  Regarding  public financial  management,  BSEB  budgets  are  prepared  annually,  and 
financial targets for all significant activities are detailed enough to provide a meaningful tool for 
monitoring subsequent performance. Actual expenditure is compared with budgeted targets, 
significant variations are reviewed, and corrective actions are taken. No major issues were 
observed regarding BSEB’s accounting and internal control. However, more computerization 
could considerably simplify record keeping. BSEB recognizes that internal auditing plays an 
important role in ensuring good corporate governance and has internal audit functions in place. 
External auditors have raised no major accountability issues in their three most recent annual 
reports.  
 
27.  The procurement and payment process will follow a cross-checking principle. Based on 
project  requirements,  the  Store  and  Purchase  Department  requests  its  Central  Purchase 
Committee, which is headed by the BSEB chair, to approve the procurement process of goods 
and spares. The Store and Purchase Department then carries out a competitive bidding process 
for the procurement of goods. After the selection of the lowest bidder, the Central Purchase 
Committee  compares  the  cost  of  the  goods  with  the  approved  budget  before  approving 
issuance of the purchase order. The Store and Purchase Department then issues the purchase

D.  Poverty and Social 
30.  Adequate power supply is essential to sustain economic growth. Regular and efficient 
power supply is correlated to poverty reduction. Indian states like Punjab, Haryana, and Gujarat, 
with high levels of power generation and consumption, also have lower poverty rates. Bihar is 
one of the poorest states in India, with about 40% of the population classified as poor. Bihar 
also has one of the lowest electrification rates in India: only 41% of villages have electricity 
(versus an 84% national average) and only about 10% of households (versus a 56% national 
average). The project will cover seven districts: Bhojpur, Begusarai, West Chanparan, Buxar, 
East Chanparan, Samastipur, and Nalanda. Agriculture is the primary economic activity in all 
these areas, and access to reliable electricity supplies is wanting.  
 
31.  The benefits of improving the power sector are manifold. Technical developments and 
reforms that lead to sector sustainability can free up resources for other pro-poor initiatives. 
Greater and more reliable power supply helps bolster social services as hospitals, schools, and 
other social entities often suffer most from patchy and low-quality power supply, and load 
shedding.  Socially,  efficient  power  supply  increases  access  to  electronic  media  such  as 
television and radio, allowing better informed choices and greater understanding of civic affairs. 
Developing  Bihar’s  power  sector  will  boost  farm  mechanization  and  agricultural  yield,  and 
benefit  the  commercial  and  industrial  sectors  through  business  expansion  and  more 
employment opportunities. Regular power supply will also shore up household activities and 
cottage industries. All these factors help reduce poverty. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
32.  The project is classified under environment category B. Major components proposed 
under this project are supply and installation of transmission substations and transmission lines, 
as well as distribution substations and distribution lines. The civil construction work is limited to 
building foundations for the transmission towers, distribution poles, and substations. Project 
activities are proposed mainly in major towns and will be carried out mainly on government-
owned land. Some private land will be required for which resettlement plans in line with ADB's 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  are  developed  and  will  be  implemented.  No  forest  or 
sensitive areas such as national parks or wildlife sanctuaries are affected by project activities. 
                                                
22  Project Administration Manual (Appendix 2).

9 
The routes of the transmission and distribution lines will not cross such areas. Environmental 
issues identified are typical for the type of component construction, and a range of proven 
mitigation  strategies  exist  to  address  them.  There  are  adequate  budgetary  provisions  for 
implementation of the environment management plan (EMP). The EMP is part of the bidding 
documents,  and  the  executing  agency  will  supervise  the  construction  contracts  and  EMP 
implementation. Quarterly progress reports of its implementation will be submitted to ADB. In 
the  event  of  any  change  of  alignment  of  the  transmission  lines  or  the  substations,  or 
identification  of  any  unanticipated  environmental  impacts  during  the  course  of  project 
implementation, the executing agency will revise the EMP accordingly. Initial environmental 
examinations were prepared in accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement.23  
 
33.  The  project  is  classified  under  involuntary  resettlement  category  B  and  indigenous 
peoples category C. Census surveys and consultations were undertaken in accordance with 
ADB's Safeguards Policy Statement. Construction of the three transmission substations will 
require acquisition of 4.1 hectares of privately owned land.24 The social census identified the 
resettlement impacts as insignificant,25 affecting nine households in project vicinity that will be 
compensated for the loss of agricultural land.26 The construction of transmission lines will not 
require permanent land acquisition. Regarding gender issues, the loan agreements include a 
standard assurance related to core labor standards for contractors (including equal pay for 
equal type of work), and an awareness program on HIV and sexually transmitted diseases and 
human trafficking.27  
 
34.  As  this  project  will  be  the  first  externally  financed  project  for  BSEB,  the  project 
management unit will need capacity development relating to safeguard compliance, monitoring, 
and management of environmental management and resettlement plans during implementation. 
Requisite  training  of  project  management  unit  staff  is  planned,  as  well  as  implementation 
support designed to transfer knowledge of implementation matters to the executing agency. 
Details are included in the project administration manual.28 
  
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
35.  A broad risk is that capacity constraints within BSEB—including those related to financial 
management,  governance,  and  implementation  matters—could  cause  delays  in  achieving 
project  outcomes.  These  risks  are  mitigated  by  management  commitment  and  sound 
supervision  built  into  the  project  design  through  implementation  support  and  capacity 
development. Overall, the integrated benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs. 
 
36.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.29

fewer than 10% of their productive assets (income-generating).

V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
37.  The government and BSEB have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
38.  The government and BSEB have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement.  
 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve the loan of $132,200,000 to India for the Bihar Power System Improvement Project 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources,  with interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, 
including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.
